awd_titl_txt: Bridge to the Doctorate: OK-LSAMP Cohort 9 - Building Sustained Communities to Diversify the Graduate STEM Workforce and Professoriate
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities." The University of Oklahoma, a member institution of the Oklahoma LSAMP alliance (OK-AMP), proposes an integrated model of social supports and community networks to support the graduate education for 12 graduate students from underrepresented groups as Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Fellows for two years.

Bridge to the Doctorate: OK-LSAMP will integrate Social Cognitive Career Theory and Social Capital Theory into a research-based mentoring program for optimizing academic, personal, and professional development of 12 BD Fellows. The mentoring program focuses on helping Fellows develop multi-layered communities of support.  The project seeks to institutionalize a culture that enhances the personal and professional development and improve retention to PhD for all STEM graduate students.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
OK-LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate Program at the University of Oklahoma (Cohort 9)

The University of Oklahoma Bridge to the Doctorate program recruited and supported twelve Fellows to pursue graduate study in biology, chemical engineering, chemistry, civil engineering, computer science, electrical engineering, mathematics, mechanical engineering, and physics. The students were recruited across four academic years:
2017-2018: One recruited fall 2017; one recruited spring 2018
2018-2019: Six recruited fall 2018
2019-2020: Three recruited fall 2019 (one of whom deferred to fall 2020)
2020-2021: One recruited fall 2020

The Bridge to the Doctorate program offered individualized research mentorship, monthly group meetings for Fellows, frequent professional development opportunities, and individualized meetings and support by program leadership. During the 2019-2020 academic year, we implemented a new strategy of referring each Fellow to a trained Academic Life Coach who could meet with them one-on-one on a weekly or biweekly basis to find strategies to address any academic and personal challenges they might be facing. We worked directly with the mentors of newly recruited Fellows to establish mentoring agreements and mentorship strategies and offered workshops on applying for the NSF Graduate Research Fellows Program.

At the end of the performance period, three Fellows were still actively pursuing their PhD degrees; four additional Fellows had completed their master's degrees; one was still pursuing a master's degree; and four (including the two Fellows who began in fall 2020) were no longer enrolled. One Bridge to the Doctorate Fellow earned SMART and GEM Fellowships to support pursuit of the PhD, one earned an NSF GRFP award, one was supported by an NSF NRT award, and others were supported through departmental funding.

Despite the disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic and global racial justice uprising, which were major stressors for program participants and resulted in all program activities being conducted online for the final 17 months of the performance period, this program facilitated successful graduate study for many Fellows, broadening participation in academic and non-academic professional pathways and STEM research. Fellows reported to the external evaluator that they would have been unable to pursue graduate study without the Bridge to the Doctorate Fellowship and valued the individualized support they received. Analysis by the external evaluator shows that Bridge to the Doctorate Fellows experienced less attrition than their peers from fall 2017 to fall 2020 (the latest date for which full attrition data are available), suggesting that the mentorship, professional development, and community-building activities they experienced contributed to their academic success and persistence.

In addition, the lessons we learned from interacting with the Fellows during overlapping public health and political crises are helping us to develop an improved strategy to build a mentorship team for each STEM graduate student member of a historically underrepresented group to provide comprehensive, 360-degree support regarding research, coursework, professional networking, mental and physical health, financial management, family situations, and other personal and academic challenges. Our experience with this cohort of Bridge to the Doctorate Fellows is helping us improve the climate, experience, and success rate of many other graduate students on our campus.


Last Modified: 11/11/2021
Modified by: Sherri Irvin
